speaker: Frasier
text: You're listening to KACL 780 on your AM dial.  This is Dr. Frasier Crane.  All our lines are open, so please, give us a call. [_silence_] I'm just sitting here waiting. [_silence_] Hey, Seattle, c'mon, I know you're out there.  Hey, look, I realise it's a sunny day but on all those rainy days, I was there for you. [_silence_] Well, alright then, if that's the way you want it, you leave me no recourse... [_clears his throat; singing_] "When the moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie-"

speaker: Frasier
text: _That_ seems to have gotten you going there, okay!  Alright then, I knew you were out there.  Okay, Roz, who do we have?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Gary from Issiqua on line two.  He and his wife had a big fight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sorry to hear that, Gar.  I'm listening.

speaker: Gary
text: [_v.o._] Well, y'see, Dr. Crane, my wife is hell-bent on going to Italy this year.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ahh, Italia - the rolling hills of Toscana, the art of Firenze, the passion that is Venizia...

speaker: Gary
text: [_over his head_] Yeah, well, anyway - I like taking vacations as much as the next guy but I say that, if we dip into our savings, I think the first thing we should buy is a new sump-pump for the basement.  At least with that-

speaker: Frasier
text: [_interrupting_] Oh, listen, Gary.  Let me stop you right there.  I'm afraid I'm going to have to side with your wife on this one.

speaker: Gary
text: But the trip to Italy costs eighteen hundred bucks, and that doesn't include the "Splendours of the Vatican" package.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gary, there is more to life than sump-pumps.  Whatever happened to feeding our souls?  Look, for example, I recently purchased a painting by one of this country's premier artists-- oh, it's not important who.  Well, it's Seattle's own Martha Paxton, but... Practical?  No.  But ever since acquiring that painting, I look at it every day and there's not a moment when I do that I'm not uplifted by its beauty.  So Gary, go to Italy, bring back a suitcase full of memories.  Will you do that?

speaker: Gary
text: I still think I should get the sump-pump.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_contemptuous_] Well then, yes, Gary, you... you should get the sump-pump!  We'll be right back after this newsbreak.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, just what is a "sump-pump?"

speaker: Roz
text: If you need one, you'll know.  Listen, do you really own a Paxton or were you just blowing sunshine up old Gary's skirt?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes indeed, I do own a Paxton.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, you'll be pleased to know that she's on line three. [_holds up the phone_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gasps and snatches the phone_] My God, Roz, she's the preeminent Neofauvist of the twentieth century!  How could you put her on hold?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, the phone rang and I pushed the little button-

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, hello, Miss Paxton.  I'm so sorry to have kept you waiting.  Well, thank you.  I'm very flattered that you listen to my little show.  Yes, well, yes, I meant every word.  Yes, that's lovely, I'd like to meet you, too sometime. [_sudden thought_] As a matter of fact, I'm having a few friends over for a little gathering this Friday night, for cocktails and such.  Well, I suppose you're far too busy to... you would! Oh, that's marvelous.  Alright, that's the Elliot Bay towers on the Counterbalance.  Around seven is just fine.  And, well, I'll see then then.  _Ciao!_ [_hangs up_]

speaker: Roz
text: I didn't know you were having a cocktail party.

speaker: Frasier
text: That makes two of us! **WHAT A SWELL PARTY**  _Scene B - Frasier's apartment, Friday night. The cocktail party has started.  Martha Paxton's painting occupies a place of honor over the fireplace.  Daphne is standing in the middle of a small clique, while the rest of the party mingle around them.  Niles is seated on the stereo cabinet, gazing at her adoringly._

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, my theory on death is: first you're whisked down a long dark tunnel towards a beautiful white light; you suddenly get all the jokes you never got before, you let out a little chuckle, and then you die!

speaker: Frasier
text: That's a delightful story, Daphne, but I think the toast points need replenishing.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_moving away_] Be right on it.

speaker: Niles
text: [_hops down_] Enchanting, just enchanting.

speaker: Frasier
text: My God, Niles, why is no-one eating the Mussoline of Duck?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you mangy little cur! [_chases Eddie away_]

speaker: Niles
text: Well, now we know why.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, Niles, the dog is eating the food, the pianist is too intrusive, the Pinot Noir is far too stagey and it's five past seven and Martha isn't even here yet!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm not going to have to sedate you, am I?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm just a bit on edge, I want everything to be so perfect. [_pause_] By the way, where's Maris?  I haven't seen her all night.

speaker: Niles
text: She's on your bed.

speaker: Frasier
text: My bed?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, she's asleep under the guests' coats.  She exhausts easily under the pressure to be interesting.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, she's supposed to be looking after dad.  That's the only reason you're here, remember?

speaker: Niles
text: Dad is in the bathroom - don't worry.

speaker: Frasier
text: That must be la Paxton - and fashionably late, of course.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh hi, Roz, it's you. [_she looks offended_] And you look radiant.

speaker: Roz
text: I look like crap - I've got a spot on my dress, I over-plucked one eyebrow and the crotch of my pantyhose is creeping down to my knees.  _To Frasier's horror she squats behind the table next to the couch and pulls them up._

speaker: Frasier
text: Couldn't you have just done that in the elevator? [_takes her coat_] Oh, my goodness, Roz, you've got a neck.  Gee, so what do you think of the place?  Is it everything you imagined it would be?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, to be frank, Frasier, I don't spend my idle hours imagining how you live.  But I did expect lots of beige and, look, I was right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you like a drink?

speaker: Roz
text: Sure, something light would be nice.

speaker: Roz
text: [_to waiter_] Double bourbon, rocks, and spill a little in the glass.  _In the Kitchen, Daphne is bent over, taking a tray out of the oven. Niles sidles in, apparently innocently._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Daphne, you're here, too.

speaker: Daphne
text: My goodness, Dr. Crane - shouldn't you be out there mixing?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, don't mind me.  I'm just getting some ice. [_puts the ice to his forehead_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Lovely party, isn't it?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, it is.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_chopping herbs_] ook at this fresh fennel. [_picks up a piece and sniffs it_] Smells wonderful, doesn't it?

speaker: Niles
text: [_smelling Daphne's hair instead_] It certainly does.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_catching Niles_] Dr. Crane, were you sniffing my hair?

speaker: Niles
text: Why would I do a thing like that?  I'm a happily married man - I love my Maris.

speaker: Guest
text: [_entering kitchen_] Where should I put this coat?

speaker: Niles
text: Just throw it on the bed.

speaker: Roz
text: So, Frasier, which one is your dad?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well, he's the older gentleman over there talking to Bethany van Pelt, showing her the photographs. [_realises_] Oh my God!

speaker: Martin
text: [_re: photos_] ...and when we finally got to her it was only hanging by two tendons.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Bethany, who looks ill_] Would you excuse us, please? [_leads his dad away_] Dad, will you stop showing these crime scene photos?  You're embarrassing me.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, these society people eat this up.  Besides, she was the one that brought it up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, she brought it up?  Bethany van Pelt - the head of the Junior League - brought up the subject of a hooker whose body was hideously dismembered and scattered all over an abandoned warehouse.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, she asked, "aren't these Swedish meatballs the messiest things you've ever seen?" and I said, "no, as a matter of fact"-

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, dad, please!

speaker: Martin
text: Alright, alright, but stop shadowing me.  I don't need a nursemaid.

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, if you give me your word, that's good enough for me.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_hits Niles_] You watch him!  _As Frasier moves off, Niles would obviously prefer to stay with Daphne, when Roz comes over to him._

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, hello.

speaker: Roz
text: You may not remember me, I'm-

speaker: Niles
text: Of course I remember you.  Would you be a love and watch that man with the cane? [_continues following Daphne_]  _Doorbell rings.  Frasier answers - this time, it is Martha Paxton. She is short, bald and aged around 50.  She wears a poncho which covers her arms completely, and a Native American bead necklace._

speaker: Martha
text: Dr. Crane?  I'm Martha Paxton.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course, who else could you be?  Welcome to my salon. [_loudly_] Everyone, everyone, your attention, please.  I'd like you all to welcome our guest of honour, the renowned artist - Martha Paxton.

speaker: Frasier
text: May I take your... poncho?

speaker: Martha
text: No, no, no, no, I never take it off at parties.  It gives me an excuse not to shake hands with people.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, how delightfully eccentric!  You must meet my brother, Niles.  Oh, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: [_moves over to the door_] Miss Paxton, Dr. Niles Crane.  It is an honour to shake your hand. [_outstretches his hand then, seeing no reaction on her part, shakes her poncho instead_] Well, to shake anything of yours is an honour. [_skulks away, embarrassed_]

speaker: Martha
text: Now, where did you hang my painting?  I'm always curious to know how people live with my work.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Live with my work" - I love that phrase.  If you would, right this way, please. [_leads her towards the centre of the room_] I think this is the perfect spot for an ideal viewing.  Oh God, I've waited so long for this moment - I'm just going to stand back and let you describe your work - "Elegy in Green"-- in your own words.  The way you insinuate the palette but never lean on it, you capture the _zeitgeist_ of our generation. It is the most perfect canvas it has ever my privilege to gaze upon.  I mean, one can only imagine what inspired you to paint it.

speaker: Martha
text: I didn't paint it.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_fighting panic_] Of course you didn't.  You-you created it, you gave birth to it.

speaker: Martha
text: [_walks to the painting_] I didn't do anything to it - I never saw this _painting_ before in my whole life.

speaker: Martin
text: [_leans into Frasier's ear_] And you thought I was gonna embarrass you!  _End Of Act One.  Act Two.  Scene C - Frasier's apartment, post-party.  Martin and Frasier are in the lounge.  Daphne is cleaning up while Frasier just leans against the pillar, staring at the painting._

speaker: Martin
text: I really liked your friend Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: Roz, at the party tonight.  Nice gal.  Why don't you ask her out?  She's great-looking and she can really hold her liquor.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, do you mind?  I've just suffered the most humiliating evening of my life.  I've been been made a fool of by this, this, this... thing. [_gestures towards the painting_]

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, I may be just a girl from Manchester but, I have to tell you, even though it's not a Paxton, I really like that picture.  I liked it the minute I saw it.  I liked it even before I knew who Martha Paxton was.  And quite frankly, I don't think that woman bathes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, enjoy it while you can because, first thing in the morning, this is going back to the dealer where I bought it. I'm demanding my money back - no-one is going to take advantage of Frasier Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: You know, listen, Frasier.  You're kind of upset about this, maybe I should return it for you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Dad, I appreciate the gesture but, really, what do you know about the art world?

speaker: Martin
text: Apparently about as much as you do. **#$ &%*!!!**  _Scene B - The Hayson Gallery Frasier is staring at a painting, he is approached by Phillip._

speaker: Phillip
text: I can see the love in your eyes.  You must have this painting.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you the owner?

speaker: Phillip
text: Yes, I am.  Phillip Hayson. [_they shake hands_]

speaker: Frasier
text: How do you do, I'm Dr. Frasier Crane.  I happen -

speaker: Phillip
text: No, not _the_ Dr. Frasier Crane.  From the radio?

speaker: Frasier
text: Guilty.  Yes, but -

speaker: Phillip
text: My wife and I love your show!  Could I have your autograph before you go?

speaker: Frasier
text: It would be my pleasure but, speaking of autographs, I have a small problem with this painting. [_holds up painting_]

speaker: Phillip
text: I'm really distressed to hear that.  Would you like a glass of wine?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually I -

speaker: Phillip
text: My wife and I toured the Loire valley last year and we couldn't resist buying four cases of this.  [_opens the bottle and pours Frasier a glass_] It's really quite extraordinary - I hope you like it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'd really rather not have any wine at this moment -

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's rather nice, isn't it?  Finishes well.

speaker: Phillip
text: Very well.  Would you like some more?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, thank you.  I'd... getting back to my problem - I recently gave a small but elegant soiree at which Martha Paxton was in attendance, you see.  She told me that this painting was not her work.

speaker: Phillip
text: Oh dear, I can imagine how embarrassing that must have been.

speaker: Frasier
text: I doubt you can, Mr. Hayson.

speaker: Phillip
text: Please, Phillip.  Let's take a look at that in slightly better light, shall we? [_walks the painting over to a stand and places it on the easel_] Oh, yes, I remember this - it's breathtaking.  [_Raising his voice_] Ronald, Diane, will you step in here a moment please?  _Two of Phillip's shills come through to join them, they gather around the painting._

speaker: Phillip
text: Do you remember when this piece was in the gallery - everyone who saw it wanted it.

speaker: Diane
text: Yes, it's a very special piece.

speaker: Ronald
text: Mrs. Chitcherelli was heart broken when it sold.

speaker: Phillip
text: Oh, I remember -

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I'm sure she was but, you see, it's _not_ a Paxton!

speaker: Phillip
text: But it says right here that it _is_ a Paxton.  The signature is here. [_The three bend to point at the signature_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Martha Paxton says that it is not a Paxton.

speaker: Phillip
text: Oh, Martha, how is the old dear?  Her and I go back a long way, is she still-? [_makes a gesture to his hair - a reference to Paxton's baldness_]

speaker: Frasier
text: As a Crenshaw melon, yes.

speaker: Phillip
text: Would you like a little more wine?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I don't want any wine.  I want to discuss this painting.

speaker: Phillip
text: So would I.  Maybe some brie? [_Ronald and Diane disappear_]

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I don't want any brie!  I want my money back.

speaker: Phillip
text: Oh, well, that's where things might get a bit... prickly. You see, we have a strict policy here at the Hayson gallery - all sales are final.

speaker: Frasier
text: But, in this case, you're willing to make an exception.

speaker: Phillip
text: Oh, I'd love to, but I can't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but it's a forgery.

speaker: Phillip
text: Well, if it is, it's a damn good one. [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, alright, I'm going to make this simple - I want my money.

speaker: Phillip
text: I'm sure you do.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I know what you're doing - you're "handling" me.  You're agreeing with everything I say hoping I'll tire and go away.

speaker: Phillip
text: Whatever you say.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't believe it!  You're shining me on.  You are shining me on!  Where is the fairness of this, where is the justice?!

speaker: Phillip
text: Dr. Crane, if you ever find justice in this world, let me know, will you?  Now, if you'll excuse me, I have work to do. [_walks away_]

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  Did a crate of freshly-painted Rembrandts just arrive?! [_follows him_] Damn it, you're not getting away with this! I am not leaving.  I am not leaving!  I am NOT leaving. **AFTER HE LEFT...**  _Scene C - Frasier's apartment. Frasier arrives, with the painting, to find Martin eating at the dinner table._

speaker: Martin
text: What are you still doing with that?  I thought you were going to return it.

speaker: Frasier
text: They wouldn't take it back.  All I got was some attitude and a cheap glass of wine - Loire valley, my ass.

speaker: Martin
text: What are you going to do now?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, they've forced my hand.  I'm going to call the police. [_picks up the phone_]

speaker: Martin
text: Five-five-five three thousand.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad.  Try to mess with Dr. Frasier Crane, I'll teach them. [_into phone_] Hello, yes.  Oh, just a second. [_to Martin_] Dad, who do I ask for?

speaker: Martin
text: Have them put you through to the fine arts forgery department.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_into phone_] Hello, yes, the fine arts forgery department, please.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, they're laughing at me.

speaker: Martin
text: [_chuckling_] Give me the phone. [_Frasier does_] Hi, who's this? Hey, Doris.  Yeah, Marty Crane.  Yeah, that was my son.  Yeah, I just thought he needed a bite of a reality sandwich.  Yeah, yeah, give my best to the guys.  Thanks.  Bye. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: What was that?

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, the boys downtown have their hands full of murders and robberies - they don't have time for this artsy-fartsy stuff.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Dad, but what am I supposed to do?  I've been cheated!  _Niles and Daphne emerge from Frasier's bedroom, both are disheveled and appear straightening their clothes._

speaker: Frasier
text: What were you two doing back there?

speaker: Niles
text: Maris lost her earring at the party last night.  Daphne was good enough to crawl under the bed to look for it while I...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_long and low_] Yeeeess?

speaker: Niles
text: Searched the credenza!

speaker: Daphne
text: Maybe I'll go check in the hallway.  It might have gotten trampled into the carpet when everybody stampeded for the elevator.

speaker: Frasier
text: No one stampeded!  They were all just good guests, they knew when to leave.

speaker: Niles
text: Two hours early. [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, shut up, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: [_sees the painting_] Oh, I see.  Am I to ascribe this foul mood to the fact that you were unable to unload the bogus Paxton?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Gee, I know, Niles.  What is the name of that really vicious lawyer that you use?

speaker: Niles
text: Which one, the one I used to sue the contractor or the one I used to sue the personal trainer?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the meanest.

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, that would be the second one.  I used him to sue the first one.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right. [_picks up the phone_] Ah, just give me his number, will you?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, forget it, Frasier.  Five years of litigation and you'll end up paying eight times what you paid for the painting. [_carries his plate to the kitchen_]

speaker: Niles
text: He's right about that.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_replaces the phone_] God, I hate laywers!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, me too. [_sits down on the couch_]  But they make wonderful patients.  They have excellent health insurance and they never get better.

speaker: Frasier
text: Say, I know, I know.  I can use my radio show - why didn't I think of this earlier?  I can use my bully pulpit to expose that man for the fraud that he is!

speaker: Niles
text: Now, Frasier, that's slander.  He'll sue you for everything you've got.

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn it, Niles, where is the justice?  Where am I supposed to turn to?  I'm a, a beloved household personality and I've been screwed! [_gestures at the painting_]

speaker: Martin
text: [_as he returns from the kitchen_] For God's sake, Frasier, you're forty-one years old.  It's time you learned something: the system ain't perfect.  Sometimes the bad guy wins.  And all those things you thought would be around to help you, the courts and the police department?  Well, sometimes they're just not there when you need them.  So you can either let it eat a hole in your stomach, or you can just file it away under the heading, "Sometimes Life Sucks." [_exits to his room_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shouts after him_] Yeah well, that file's getting pretty thick!  _Niles returns from the bar with two sherries.  He hands one to Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: So that's that, huh?  Hayson just gets away with it.  He's sitting there now with his brie and his wine and his little chuckle at my expense.  Gosh, you know, I finally understand why people take matters into their own hands.  It would be so satisfying right now to just... slash his tires, or... throw a brick though his window or something.  Just so he'd learn that you don't do this to people and get away with it.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, well, I know you, Frasier, and I know that you'd never resort to that sort of thing. [_looks at his brother, and becomes unsure_] Would you, Frasier?

speaker: Niles
text: There's a vein throbbing in your forehead.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I couldn't find it in the hallway but let me give it one last try.  Could you give me the matching earring?  Maybe I'll get something from it.  _Niles hands Daphne the earring.  She holds it in both hands and concentrates._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh yes, I'm getting a feeling.  It's in your father's room. No, no, it's in Dr. Crane's room.  Oh, this is odd, now it's in the hallway.

speaker: Niles/Daphne
text: ** Eddie!  _Niles and Daphne run after Eddie while Frasier grabs his car keys and exits the apartment.  FADE TO:_  **PEACHFUZZ**  _Scene D - Outside the Hayson Gallery. Frasier creeps round the corner, holding a brick.  He checks that the coast is clear, then stands in front of the window and is about to throw it until he notices an old couple walking past.  He hides the brick behind his back._

speaker: Frasier
text: Good evening.  Lovely night, isn't it?  Yes, well, goodnight.  _Again, Frasier gets ready to throw the brick but this time a horn honks and Niles's car pulls up in front of the gallery._

speaker: Niles
text: [_through car window_] Get in the car.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what the hell are you doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: Stopping you from doing something really stupid.  Now get in the car.

speaker: Frasier
text: I will not!  Niles, look, I know this is wrong but I don't care!  It's the only thing left for me!

speaker: Niles
text: Alright, Frasier. [_steps out of the car; Frasier retreats_] Frasier, just give me the brick and no one will get hurt.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why don't you just go away?  This is no concern of yours.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, it is.

speaker: Frasier
text: How?

speaker: Niles
text: Remember that day in junior high school when somebody took all my clothes while I was in the shower, right after gym class?  They hung them from the goalpost on the football field.  I had no choice but to get a ladder and climb up there wearing nothing but a towel, wet and shivering.  Then the towel fell off!  There I was - your little brother, hanging naked from a goal post, and everyone was standing around laughing, and all Coach Medwick would do was stand there going- [_holds his arms up to imitate the gesture_] whatever that means.  [_N.B. In American football, the signal - raising the arms to vertical and then dropping them to a "Y" position - means "field goal!" when a player scores by kicking the ball over and through the goal post._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, why are you telling me this?

speaker: Niles
text: Because - I was so humiliated, I went home, I cried my eyes out, I swore I would get even.  I was just about to put sugar into Coach Medwick's gas tank... and you stopped me. Remember what you said?  "If you act like a barbarian, you will become a barbarian."

speaker: Frasier
text: I said that?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  Well, actually you were more verbose at the time. I had to listen, you were sitting on my chest.

speaker: Niles
text: Give me the brick, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_frustrated_] And let him get away with this?!

speaker: Niles
text: I know, I know!  What the gallery owner did to you was wrong, it was humiliating.  But if you throw that brick through that window, you will have lost something more valuable than your money.  You will have lost... your mind.  Frasier, you can't do this!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Niles, if you were strong enough to show restraint after so much humiliation, not to mention the nicknames.

speaker: Niles
text: [_as if remembering_] Nicknames. [_then:_] There were nicknames?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you didn't know that?  Oh dear God, yes.  Uh, "Peachfuzz," "Jingle Bells" - I can't remember the rest.

speaker: Niles
text: "Peachfuzz"?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I believe Coach Medwick made that one up himself. [_hands Niles the brick_] Well, anyway, here you are. I won't be needing this anymore.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm proud of you.  _Frasier heads towards the car but Niles does not join him.  Instead, he cocks his arm and hurls the brick through the gallery window, shattering it with a loud crash.  As the alarm sounds, Niles throws his hands up in a gesture reminiscient of the Coach Medwick signal._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shouts above the alarm_] My God, Niles!  What are you, what have you done?!

speaker: Niles
text: [_proud_] I've struck a blow for justice!  Nobody calls me "Peachfuzz."  Now let's get the hell out of here.  _They both run to the car, but as Frasier dashes to the passenger side, Niles stops and runs back to the window with his wallet out._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what are you doing now?

speaker: Niles
text: We may be barbarians, but we pay for our pillaging!

speaker: Frasier
text: Come on, come on! [_Niles gets into the car_] GO, GO, GO, GO!
